snippet.textDisplay: stadia is just a convenience product... there is no way it will have a competitive foothold against consoles and pc... game streaming is not the future because lag prevents competitive play... latency is the enemy they are fighting... if, by some miracle tech, they can figure a way to beat it out of the equation, then and only then will it have a chance of competing ... but until then, they would have to put the breaks on streaming and allow for downloading games onto hardware... maybe thats an option... maybe the controller itself is the "console". I think this is the only real way in the foreseeable future that they stand a chance in today's market.
snippet.textOriginal: stadia is just a convenience product... there is no way it will have a competitive foothold against consoles and pc... game streaming is not the future because lag prevents competitive play... latency is the enemy they are fighting... if, by some miracle tech, they can figure a way to beat it out of the equation, then and only then will it have a chance of competing ... but until then, they would have to put the breaks on streaming and allow for downloading games onto hardware... maybe thats an option... maybe the controller itself is the "console". I think this is the only real way in the foreseeable future that they stand a chance in today's market.

snippet.textDisplay: Google should not have tried to compete with steam and xbox as a marketplace for hardcore and AAA games. Consuners have high expectations and will not tolerate the intermittent lag spikes that are inevitable in a realtime stream. Instead they should have gone after the casual crowd. Games like Jack in a box, where you dont even need a controller, just smartphones. Take advantage of the no download low barrier to entry edge.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wasn't able to get my gaming pc out of storage from my parents house, and I can't use my playstation because my girlfriend's dad is paranoid about how much electricity it used (I know, crazy, he's the most frugal guy I've ever met). Anyway I realised I was in a pickle and noticed that I'd been accepted for the beta testing of Nvidia Now. The internet here is the cheapest package going, and yet surprisingly it handles it very well. It's not perfect, and actually gaming is not fun during the peak times of 6pm-midnight. But after midnight it works flawlessly. I was genuinely impressed, especially compared to other companies that had been offering the same thing already. I doubt pro gamers will ever want to use this, but in a couple of years when the dust has settled and the tech is smooth, this will be good enough for 99% of gamers, provided they have super fast broadband. In the UK it is now only around £5 more per month for super fast.

Stadia sounds like it was executed badly. Nvidia was smart and gave it out for free until they got it perfect. This is the future of gaming, just as the internet grows, so will this, it's just in its infancy at the moment.
snippet.textOriginal:

But after midnight it works flawlessly. I was genuinely impressed, especially compared to other companies that had been offering the same thing already. Stadia sounds like it was executed badly. Nvidia was smart and gave it out for free until they got it perfect. This is the future of gaming, just as the internet grows, so will this, it's just in its infancy at the moment.

snippet.textDisplay: Onlive got it right, they went through this pain originally. It odd how no lessons have been learnt from Onlive. Before Onlive was bought out by Sony for Playstation IP. They had started linking their game store with Steam. So you could pick up games cheaply on store and if it was a supported title you could run it on Onlive. Not all steam games were available but at least the ones that were meant you could purchase the game via steam and when Onlive ended you still had access too it. Long live Onlive, it worked for the most part, except I did struggle with certainly twitch sensitive titles like Dirt rally, I could feel the input lag, but I was only on a 30mbps connection with even worse upload.
snippet.textOriginal: Onlive got it right, they went through this pain originally. It odd how no lessons have been learnt from Onlive. Before Onlive was bought out by Sony for Playstation IP. They had started linking their game store with Steam. So you could pick up games cheaply on store and if it was a supported title you could run it on Onlive. Not all steam games were available but at least the ones that were meant you could purchase the game via steam and when Onlive ended you still had access too it. Long live Onlive, it worked for the most part, except I did struggle with certainly twitch sensitive titles like Dirt rally, I could feel the input lag, but I was only on a 30mbps connection with even worse upload.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have 500mbps unlimited internet at home, and no Stadia. Why? I have a PS4 and the PS Go app. It allows me to play games away from home with or without the controller WITHOUT having to buy the exact game over again and pay a subscription for the privilege (aside from PlayStation plus)
Bottom line, my console still works for single player if my internet went down or subscription expired.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have 500mbps unlimited internet at home, and no Stadia. Why? I have a PS4 and the PS Go app. It allows me to play games away from home with or without the controller WITHOUT having to buy the exact game over again and pay a subscription for the privilege (aside from PlayStation plus)
Bottom line, my console still works for single player if my internet went down or subscription expired.

snippet.textDisplay: Stadia is not trying to provide what all the other subscription services do. What you're paying for is not access to an online library of games. It's more like the Ultra Violet version of gaming where the up side is the hard computing being handled on their end and not the consumer's. This begs the question, though... How in the world do they think they're gonna keep up with the demand of gamers around the world all streaming in HD all day long at the same time? With the appetite for entertainment only being surpassed by the technology to make it even heavier in its demands, this seems like an impossible task to me. In addition, this still pushes gamers out into the realm of virtual access only to all their games. The industry seems to forget how big we are into collecting and displaying our purchases. What exactly will Best Buy be putting on their shelves if there are no games to go there and buy?
snippet.textOriginal: Stadia is not trying to provide what all the other subscription services do. What you're paying for is not access to an online library of games. It's more like the Ultra Violet version of gaming where the up side is the hard computing being handled on their end and not the consumer's. This begs the question, though... How in the world do they think they're gonna keep up with the demand of gamers around the world all streaming in HD all day long at the same time? With the appetite for entertainment only being surpassed by the technology to make it even heavier in its demands, this seems like an impossible task to me. In addition, this still pushes gamers out into the realm of virtual access only to all their games. The industry seems to forget how big we are into collecting and displaying our purchases. What exactly will Best Buy be putting on their shelves if there are no games to go there and buy?

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, Stadia is DOA to me. I already have large libraries on Xbox and Switch which I can't access with Stadia and no interest in building yet another library on a service that I can't even use traveling or off-line. Travel use is out the window as public wifi is sketchy or non-existent, hotel wi-fi robust enough to support stadia is a premium service often, and cellular isn't suitable either with harsh data caps, poor latency, and limited bandwidth. At home, why would I want to stream my games instead of playing what I already own on consoles I already own where I would play them anyway?

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, I would still be uninterested in having to buy from yet another marketplace.

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, and I were a new prospective customer with no games in any of the other marketplaces/consoles? The cost of ownership and subscription service might be more compelling for a light-weight gamer in such case.
snippet.textOriginal:

At home, why would I want to stream my games instead of playing what I already own on consoles I already own where I would play them anyway? 

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, I would still be uninterested in having to buy from yet another marketplace. 

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, and I were a new prospective customer with no games in any of the other marketplaces/consoles? The cost of ownership and subscription service might be more compelling for a light-weight gamer in such case.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder how much Google's image factors into the performance of Stadia?

The technology is interesting, but Google already knows way more about me than I'm entirely comfortable with, especially given how they're using (sometimes abusing) their position.

What would Stadia have to do to potentially gain my interest? Provide a way where they couldn't (not a promise that they wouldn't, but a verifiable mechanism where they couldn't ) extract any information from a paid Stadia account.

It's one thing to say that free access is funded by the value of the data they collect on me as I play, but as soon as they charge me anything for the service that data becomes my exclusive property, otherwise I'm not interested.

P.S. Tomorrow's Google Board Meeting:

Gameranx says we have competitors for Stadia? Bob, get your people to shadow ban results for Sony's and Microsoft's offerings on our search platform ... and include those search terms as Stadia keywords in Adsense. Thanks.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder how much Google's image factors into the performance of Stadia?

The technology is interesting, but Google already knows way more about me than I'm entirely comfortable with, especially given how they're using (sometimes abusing) their position.

What would Stadia have to do to potentially gain my interest?  Provide a way where they couldn't (not a promise that they wouldn't, but a verifiable mechanism where they *couldn't* ) extract *any* information from a paid Stadia account.

It's one thing to say that free access is funded by the value of the data they collect on me as I play, but as soon as they charge me anything for the service that data becomes my exclusive property, otherwise I'm not interested.

P.S.  Tomorrow's Google Board Meeting:

Gameranx says we have competitors for Stadia?  Bob, get your people to shadow ban results for Sony's and Microsoft's offerings on our search platform ... and include those search terms as Stadia keywords in Adsense.  Thanks.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm more interested in the con-job that is the 'new' Atari VCS than I am Stadia. Several comments here nail it - what happens to my investment when Google gets bored, forgets all about it, and then wakes up one day and shuts it all down? It's inevitable. No. Damn. Way am I giving them a dime for this. Someone will hit it out of the park with game streaming - it won't be Google.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm more interested in the con-job that is the 'new' Atari VCS than I am Stadia. Several comments here nail it - what happens to my investment when Google gets bored, forgets all about it, and then wakes up one day and shuts it all down? It's inevitable. No. Damn. Way am I giving them a dime for this. Someone will hit it out of the park with game streaming - it won't be Google.

snippet.textDisplay: I really hope Stadia fails, it needs to, otherwise a bad precedent for selling people "access" to games but not owning it will get a terrible foothold.
snippet.textOriginal: I really hope Stadia fails, it needs to, otherwise a bad precedent for selling people "access" to games but not owning it will get a terrible foothold.

snippet.textDisplay: I wish that Stadia linked to my Steam account. That would make it worth it now until they build up their catalog. I'm a founder, and believe in the idea of it. I've played it in my TV, and my Chromebook. It definitely makes me consider getting a pixel.
snippet.textOriginal: I wish that Stadia linked to my Steam account. That would make it worth it now until they build up their catalog. I'm a founder, and believe in the idea of it. I've played it in my TV, and my Chromebook. It definitely makes me consider getting a pixel.

snippet.textDisplay: There needs to be a trial or something so you can test out how it works on your network. They said they would sometime in the future, but did not say when and frankly they might change their mind. I'm using Geforce Now and It's neat but it's noticeably worse that running native with a medium PC. I would try xcloud but it's not available in my country :( I do hope game streaming succeeds sometime in the future, but I'm skeptical

snippet.textDisplay: Make it cheaper, drop a lot more games in within the month, give people what you promised in the beginning, don’t charge them more for less, you know the right thing to do. I should have been able to play games like Gears of War or Call of Duty on my iPad Pro by now. Nope I was busy lagging in 2k on my chrome browser with 5G WiFi.
snippet.textOriginal: Make it cheaper, drop a lot more games in within the month, give people what you promised in the beginning, don’t charge them more for less, you know the right thing to do. I should have been able to play games like Gears of War or Call of Duty on my iPad Pro by now. Nope I was busy lagging in 2k on my chrome browser with 5G WiFi.
